metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with the airborne WiDAS mission in the Linze station foci experimental area on Jun. 29, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with the airborne WiDAS mission was obtained in the Linze station foci experimental area on Jun. 29, 2008. WiDAS, composed of four CCD cameras, one mid-infrared thermal imager (AGEMA 550), and one infrared thermal imager (S60), can acquire CCD, MIR and TIR band data. The simultaneous ground data included:
     (1) soil moisture (0-5cm) nine times by the cutting ring (50cm^3) along LY06 and LY07 strips, and once by the cutting ring method and once by ML2X Soil Moisture Tachometer in the six points of Wulidun farmland quadrates. The preprocessed soil volumetric moisture data were archived as Excel files.
     (2) surface radiative temperature measured three times by three handheld infrared thermometer (5# and 6# from Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute, and one from Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resources, which were all calibrated) in LY06 and LY07 strips (98 sample points and repeated three times) and the Wulidun farmland quadrates (various points and repeated three times). Data were archived as Excel files.
     (3) maize canopy component temperature measured by the 5# handheld infrared thermometer (from Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute) in Wulidun farmland quadrates. Six directions were measured, canopy backlighting and frontlighting, half height backlighting and frontlighting, the light and the shaded bareland, with each direction 20 measurements. 
     (4) spectrum of maize, soil and soil with known moisture measured by ASD Spectroradiometer (350～2 500 nm) from BNU, and the reference board (40% before Jun. 15 and 20% hereafter) in Wulidun farmland quadrates. Raw spectral data were binary files , which were recorded daily in detail, and pre-processed data on reflectance (by ViewSpecPro) were archived as Excel.files
     (5) mltiangle maize spectrum measured by ASD Spectroradiometer (350～2 500 nm) from BNU, the reference board (40% before Jun. 15 and 20% hereafter), two observation platforms of BNU make and one of Institute of Remote Sensing Applications make in Wulidun farmland. Raw spectral data were archived as binary files, which were recorded daily in detail, and pre-processed data on reflectance and transmittivity were archived as text files (.txt). 
     (6) LAI of maize measured by the fisheye camera (CANON EOS40D with a lens of EF15/28), shooting straight downwards, with exceptions of higher plants, which were shot upwards. Data included original photos (.JPG) and those processed by can_eye5.0 (in excel).
     (7) LAI of maize measured by LAI2000 in Wulidun farmland quadrates. Data educed from LAI2000 periodically were archived as text files (.txt) and marked with one ID. Raw data (table of word and txt) and processed data (Excel) were included. Besides, observation time, the observation method and the repetition were all archived.
     See the metadata record “WATER: Dataset of setting of the sampling plots and stripes in the Linze station foci experimental area” for more information of the quadrate locations.

Definition.Question: What is the Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner (WiDAS) in the context of remote sensing data collection?
Definition.Answer: The Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner (WiDAS) is an airborne instrument used in remote sensing that consists of four CCD cameras, one mid-infrared thermal imager (AGEMA 550), and one thermal infrared thermal imager (S60). It simultaneously captures data in visible/near-infrared (CCD) bands at five angles, mid-infrared (MIR) at seven angles, and thermal infrared (TIR) at seven angles, providing comprehensive imaging capabilities for various remote sensing applications.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying data collection techniques can be inferred from the use of varied instruments like WiDAS, ASD spectrometers, and LAI-2000 in understanding soil moisture, temperature, and vegetation characteristics?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of WiDAS, ASD spectrometers, and LAI-2000 reflects a comprehensive data collection strategy that integrates multi-angle, multi-spectral, and multi-temporal observations. WiDAS offers simultaneous data from visible, near-infrared, mid-infrared, and thermal infrared wavelengths, allowing for detailed analysis of surface properties and conditions. The ASD spectrometer provides high-resolution spectral data, which is crucial for identifying specific characteristics of vegetation and soil. The LAI-2000 measures leaf area index, capturing the vegetation structure and density. These varied instruments collectively enable a robust understanding of environmental conditions by capturing diverse data points such as soil moisture content, surface temperature, and vegetation characteristics. This approach suggests a focus on capturing data at different scales and perspectives to ensure a comprehensive analysis of the study area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes inaccuracies in soil moisture data collection methods when utilizing both manual sampling and automated sensors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inaccuracies in soil moisture data collection may arise from the differences in sampling techniques and tools used. Manual sampling with a ring knife might introduce variability due to human error or inconsistent sampling depths, especially when collecting 0-5cm surface soil samples. Automated sensors like the ML2X soil moisture rapid tester could face calibration issues or environmental interference, leading to discrepancies between manual and sensor-based measurements. Additionally, the use of different sampling locations and frequencies might lead to variations in the collected data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to perform ground synchronous observations during an airborne remote sensing mission using a WiDAS instrument?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground synchronous observations during an airborne remote sensing mission using a WiDAS instrument involve several procedural steps: 1) Soil moisture observation using a ring knife for sampling and an ML2X soil moisture meter for repeated measurements. 2) Surface radiation temperature observation with handheld infrared thermometers, where calibration is performed using black body temperature data to correct raw measurements. 3) Corn canopy component temperature observation in multiple directions using a handheld infrared thermometer, ensuring recordings are made within the timeframe of aircraft overpass. 4) Ground object spectral measurements using an ASD spectrometer, where data is stored as both raw binary files and processed reflectance data. 5) Multi-angle spectral observation using multiple observation frames and an ASD spectrometer. 6) Fish-eye camera LAI measurement involving photographing with a Canon EOS40D and processing images with can_eye5.0 software. 7) LAI measurements using a LAI-2000 instrument, with data recorded, processed, and stored in both original and processed formats.
